In late 2019, K-pop idol Goo Hara took her own life being subject to severe online harassment. The term ‘stan’ originates from Eminem’s titular 2000 song about a fan so disturbed by his obsession with the artist that he ends up committing murder suicide. In 2025, almost every public figure has a ‘snark’ subreddit, whose participants obsessively track their every move.

title: ‘Cancel Netflix’: Elon Musk leads rightwing backlash over trans character in kids’ show
summary: Elon Musk, the richest person in the world with a net worth of approximately $500bn, has repeatedly encouraged his 227 million followers on X, the platform he controls, to cancel their Netflix subscriptions. In the past three days alone, he has posted or reposted calls to cancel Netflix for its content at least 26 times. Musk is the father of a trans daughter, Vivian Wilson, who has publicly criticized her father’s anti-trans vendetta. Netflix, a company whose executives have repeatedly invoked freedom of speech when faced with backlash for content on its platform, has not publicly responded to Musk's taunts. This is not the first time the company has come under fire from the right; in 2020, outrage over its film Cuties, which depicted underage actors performing sexualized dance routines, led to a spike in US customer cancellations, though it receded within days.

title: YouTube agrees to pay Trump $24.5m to settle lawsuit over account suspension
summary: Donald Trump filed suit against YouTube and Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai. He alleged the platform wrongly suspended his channel after the Capitol attack. YouTube said it suspended the channel because it had violated its policies. Because of the settlement, the case is now dismissed. Facebook-parent company Meta settled a similar lawsuit with Trump in January for $25m, and the social media platform X, previously Twitter, settled another for $10m in February. Most of the payout from the Meta suit will go to Trump’s presidential library fund. For the YouTube settlement, Trump has directed $22m of the payment to go to restoring and preserving the National Mall and supporting construction of the White House ballroom. The news comes just a week after YouTube announced that it would allow creators who were once banned for spreading misinformation to be reinstated.

title: Memes and nihilistic in-jokes: the online world of Charlie Kirk’s alleged killer
summary: Tyler Robinson, 22, shot and killed rightwing activist Charlie Kirk, prosecutors say. Bullet casings from the gun he allegedly fired were engraved with niche references and internet-speak. In recent years, a growing number of shooters have left behind writings that contain nihilistic in-jokes and references that aim to differentiate their extremely online cohort from the “normies” who will struggle to understand them. Robinson fits a modern trend of attackers leaving behind messages that not only show they are products of an online culture, but are in conversation with it. But there is an enormous gulf between Robinson’s path to radicalization and the radicalization of people on the left and the right. Ignoring the messier nature of modern politics in lieu of fitting into the convenient boxes of radicalization risks missing what actually drives people to commit acts of violence. And experts say young shooters, particularly young ones, don’t fit neatly into a traditional left-right spectrum but are shaped by the heavily fractured, online state.

title: The trillion-dollar AI arms race is here
summary: Artificial intelligence companies have come under fire for cannibalizing creative industries. Google announced it was planning to spend $85bn on building out its AI and cloud infrastructure just in 2025 – $10bn more than it initially predicted. Adobe, the software company best known for making creative tools such as Photoshop, says it’s trying to walk the line between developing useful AI programs and making sure artists aren’t getting the short end of the stick. The company has introduced two “creator-safe” tools, that aim to tackle issues around copyright and intellectual property. We spoke with Adobe's Andy Parsons about the burgeoning world of AI and what it means for creators and what the company is doing to address the issues that creators and artists are facing with the advent of AI, which is still in its early stages. The full interview will appear in next week's issue of TechScape, which will also feature Dara Kerr and Johana Bhuiyan.

title: Australia’s social media ban is attracting global praise – but we’re no closer to knowing how it would work
summary: Australia's social media ban on under-16s is due to come into effect in December. The ban has been praised in the US and UK, and is described as “world-leading” by the Australian government. But nine months out from the policy coming into effect, Australians are still in the dark about how our ban – which was passed by the parliament in November 2024 – will work. A trial of age assurance technology is under way, with schoolchildren still being recruited to participate. The government faces a number of hurdles before then, including figuring out what tech to use, and whether the platforms – emboldened by the apparent backing of Donald Trump – will comply. The final report is due just two months after the preliminary report in June, before the communications minister – whoever it will be after the federal election – will get to decide which platforms it applies to. There are still major concerns over how the ban will work, and who is included. TikTok and Meta, for example, are angry over the carve out YouTube received.

title: Skype got shouted down by Teams and Zoom. But it revolutionised human connection
summary: Microsoft has decided to terminate Skype, the internet telephony company it bought in 2011 for $8.5bn (£6.6bn) Its millions of hapless users are to be herded into Microsoft Teams, a virtual encampment with a brain-dead aesthetic that makes even Zoom look cool. Skype was founded in 2003 by Janus Friis (a Dane) and Niklas Zennström (a Swede) and headquartered in Luxembourg. By 2006 it had 100m registered users and by 2009 was adding about 380,000 new users each day and generating around $740m (£575m) in annual revenue. So you could say that Skype was the first European company to reach US-level scale. At which point the inevitable happened: in 2011 Skype was bought by Microsoft and absorbed into the maw of the tech colossus.

title: How the roots of the ‘PayPal mafia’ extend to apartheid South Africa
summary: Elon Musk’s promotion of far-right conspiracy theories has grown. He has taken an unhealthy interest in genetics while backing claims of a looming “white genocide” in his South African homeland. Increasingly, his language and tone have come to echo the old South Africa. Musk is part of the “PayPal mafia’ of libertarian billionaires with roots in South Africa under white rule now hugely influential in the US tech industry and politics. They include Peter Thiel, the German-born billionaire venture capitalist and PayPal cofounder, who was educated in a southern African city in the 1970s where Hitler was still openly venerated. The South Africa into which Musk was born in 1971, and to which Thiel moved as a child from Germany, was led by a prime minister, John Vorster, who had been a general in a fascist militia three decades earlier that allied itself with Hitler. The Ossewabrandwag (OB) was founded shortly before the second world war. It opposed South Africa entering the war as an ally of Britain.

title: ‘The reign of terror is over’: my weird weekend partying with the triumphant tech right
summary: Inauguration is a watershed moment for relationships between Silicon Valley and Washington. Many in the tech right resonate with the socially conservative world of the ‘new right’ Their alignment with Trump seems in part protective, an attempt to avoid being targeted by regulators or prosecutors. Most people I met over inauguration weekend were ecstatic about Trump 2.0; at the very worst, they felt cautious optimism. But they seldom expressed concern about the friendliness between Washington and the richest people and companies on earth, or what that may mean for ordinary Americans. The tech industry thinks Trump’s enthusiastic positions on defense, energy and AI will create a particularly lucrative environment. The crypto community rallied behind Trump after his reversal on Bitcoin, shifting from calling it a scam to embracing light regulation. It has some overlap with the libertarian-leaning supporters of Robert F Kennedy Jr, who are similarly skeptical of centralized authority while also more likely to embrace offbeat ideas about health and wellness. I arrived at the Maga Maha Crypto Conference just in time for the second panel of the day: “Sustainable living earth autonomy and regeneration”

title: UK Meta staff ‘concerned’ over scrapping of factcheckers and DEI programmes
summary: UK staff at Facebook owner Meta feel “concerned’ and ‘let down’ about the company’s decision to scrap factcheckers and diversity, equity and inclusion programmes. The Prospect union, which represents a growing number of UK Meta employees, has written to Meta to express staff concern. It comes as Meta, which also owns WhatsApp and Instagram, is planning to cut about 5% of its global workforce, with its poorest-performing employees most likely to leave. The move could affect about 3,600 employees globally amid a shake-up to Meta”s performance management system, as it plans to “move out low-performers faster” The union is also asking Meta to reassure staff with protected characteristics that “they will not find themselves arbitrarily placed in a performance process”.

title: Meta’s ditching of factcheckers is potentially dangerous and a disservice
summary: Mark Zuckerberg’s announcement that Meta is to follow X in introducing user-generated notes raises serious concerns. The shift will intensify pressures on vulnerable groups, including children, minorities, gender rights advocates and LGBTQ+ communities. It risks deepening societal polarisation and further fragmenting public discourse. If Meta truly aspires to be a deliberative space driven by a “global collective consciousness that keeps each other accountable” – as suggested by Linda Yaccarino, the head of X – the company must establish structures that penalise coercion, foster reciprocity and ensure that diverse voices are heard. A reasonable precondition of this letter being published is the divulging of my home address to the Guardian. The name you see below is my real name. The Guardian can call me any time to check.

title: Historic town founded by Black Colombians fleeing slavery eyes second ‘independence’
summary: San Basilio de Palenque is the most famous Colombian palenque - the name given to communities formed by formerly enslaved people who escaped bondage. The town even has its own language, Palenquero, a mix of Spanish, Portuguese and African Bantu languages such as Kikongo and Kimbundu. Residents of the community, just 30 miles away from the touristic hub of Cartagena, are set to vote on finally becoming an independent town. But there is a sharp contrast between its cultural and historic significance and the profound lack of basic public services such as running water and sanitation. It remains unclear what form its new political organisation will take in the village, which is now headed by a council-led community board. Next month’s referendum is one of the final steps in that process, but there is still no indication of when the city will hold its first local elections. “We also still don’t know, for instance, what will happen to our ancestral justice system,” said Bernardino Pérez, 25, a community narrator.

title: ‘Trump is killing poor people’: Caribbean village mourns victim of US strike
summary: Chad “Charpo” Joseph and Rishi Samaroo are believed to have been killed. They are thought to be among six people killed in a US airstrike on a boat. Trump has described the six killed as “narcoterrorists”, claiming that “intelligence confirmed the vessel was trafficking narcotics’ Joseph’s cousin La Toya, 42, said he was denied the basic right to due process and accused the Trinidad and Tobago government of giving up its sovereignty to the US. At a wake for the two men late on Thursday, family and community members said they felt betrayed by their own government and at the mercy of a Trump administration that has been given unfettered access to their waters. “Everybody hurt, because in this community everybody is family and friends and everybody close,” one woman said.

title: Church of Norway says sorry to LGBTQ+ people for ‘shame, great harm and pain’
summary: The Church of Norway apologised for the discrimination and harm it had inflicted. The church had long marginalised LGBTQ+ people, refusing to allow them to become pastors or to marry in church. The apology took place at the London Pub, one of two bars targeted in the 2022 shooting that killed two people and left nine seriously injured during Oslo’s Pride celebrations. A Norwegian of Iranian origin, who had pledged allegiance to Islamic State, was sentenced to at least 30 years in prison for the killings. In 2023, the Church of England apologised for what it described as its “shameful” treatment, though it continues to refuse to allow same-sex marriages inChurch. The United Church of Canada offered an apology to two spirit and LGBTQIA+ communities, describing it as a reaffirmation of the church's “commitment to radical hospitality and full inclusion”

title: Miss Major, trailblazing US trans rights activist and Stonewall veteran, dies aged 78
summary: Miss Major Griffin-Gracy died at her home in Little Rock, Arkansas, surrounded by family, the House of gg announced. She was one of the US’s most celebrated trans rights pioneers and elders, at the forefront of the fight for trans rights for more than five decades. Miss Major earned a reputation as an outspoken and fearless champion for the liberation of Black trans women, fighting for communities that have long suffered extreme discrimination and violence and have been neglected by the gay rights movement. She spent her final years providing a sanctuary for trans and gender-nonconforming people in her conservative home state, while continuing to travel the country to rally fortrans rights and meet with young trans people and other LGBTQ+ organizers. Her mantra, “I’m still fucking here!”, captured the joy and humor she brought to her activism and became a rallying cry for the resiliency of Blacktrans people. The group did not give a cause of death; Miss Major suffered repeated health challenges in recent years.

title: The Supremes, Marcus Garvey, Tupac Shakur: the cultural figures who inspired our Black History Month panel
summary: Percival Everett showed me the transformative power of literature. Winifred Atwell’s virtuosic musicianship was an early lesson in freedom. Pan-Africanism awakened my fascination with history. Gamal Abdel Nasser, of Egypt, helped shape my view of pan- Africanism. YolanDa Brown Saxophonist, composer, broadcaster and chair of the British Phonographic Industry. Lenny Henry Actor, writer and comedian and the author, with Marcus Ryder, of The Big Payback: The Case for Reparations for Slavery and How They Would Work Black culture is a dynamic force that continually reshapes my identity and worldview through its art, writes Lenny. The author, who is of African descent, is also the author of a book about the history of slavery in the US, The Long and Winding Road, which is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99. For more information, visit www.thelongandwindingroad.com.

title: Guyana in turmoil after opposition leader arrested and faces US extradition
summary: Azruddin Mohamed, 38, and his father, Nazar Mohamed, 73, were arrested on 31 October in the capital, Georgetown, in response to a formal extradition request from the US government. Facing 11 charges in a Florida court – including money laundering, bribery and tax evasion – they were released later the same day after posting bail of 150,000 Guyanese dollars each (about £547 or $719.95) Mohamed has claimed they are victims of political persecution by Irfaan Ali’s government. The case has become emblematic at a time when relations between the Caribbean nation and the US have taken on new energy significance. American companies are leading the oil exploration that could soon make Guyana the world’S largest producer per capita.

title: Spirituality isn’t rigid dogma. It’s a living, breathing practice that helps make sense of an incomprehensible world
summary: When I was leaving London for Melbourne, my eldest sister-in-law told her kids not to forget the ‘tradition’ – to throw a bowl of water behind me as I stepped out the door. “La har azaab po aman se,” she whispered in Pashto under her breath – may all hardship stay away from you. My mother used to do this too, back in Afghanistan. Every time I left for a journey, especially international ones, she’d quietly follow me to the gate. Drawing on her own encounters, I’ve come to see how these seemingly small gestures – the fragrant smoke of esfand to lift heaviness, the rhythmic pull of qawwali, the quiet assurance of a taweez tied around a wrist – hold more than superstition. They carry virtues: grounding, comfort and a deep sense of protection.

title: Threats, fear and hope as Mumbai slum dwellers await the bulldozers
summary: Dharavi is one of India’s largest and most storied slums. It will be bulldozed and redeveloped by the multinational conglomerate Adani Group. Of the roughly 1 million residents living in the dense 220-hectare (2.2 sq km) area, fewer than half will be eligible for new homes in the development. Others will be moved to wastelands and salt plains on the far outskirts of the city, threatening to fragment a generations-old community. Those allowed to remain in Dharavi will be given apartments in tower blocks, a significant rupture from the organic, communal way of living and working that has sustained DHaravi for so long. The group has faced accusations of financial impropriety and crony capitalism. Since they began to oppose the development, they have been vocally and vocally supported by the Indian government. A court case alleging that the project was unfairly awarded to Adani is being considered in India's supreme court.

title: Trump’s megalomaniac White House project fits a global trend among far-right populists
summary: Far-right populist leaders in many countries have used spectacular architecture to advance their political agenda. Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, has had massive structures erected, from a gigantic mosque in Istanbul to a new presidential palace in Ankara. In his use of the built environment, Trump is less an example of American exceptionalism than is suggested by credulous accounts of “Trump, ever the developer”. But some promoters of classicism have talked about “classical buildings making us proud of our country” Magistrates in Italy are modernist marvels; it only legitimizes it easily. Even if such autocratic figures were removed from office – and of course they do everything to avoid that outcome – their edifices and monuments will remain. The implicit claim is: “We won and now the country is ours!”

title: Big? Beautiful? Donald Trump is literally ripping apart the home of US democracy. Is anyone really surprised?
summary: demolition crews moved into the White House to knock down part of the East Wing at the behest of Donald Trump. As far as we can tell, Trump didn’t actually send in a wrecking ball – although his administration did sharply reprimand government employees working in a neighbouring Treasury building for posting visuals of the demolition online. The Society of Architectural Historians released a statement expressing ‘great concern’ over the proposed ballroom. The American Institute of Architects put out a stiff note reminding the president that “the historic edifice at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue is the People’s House, a national treasure and an enduring symbol of our democracy”. The ballroom will be funded via private donations via the Trump International Hotel, offering the possibility of a future use for the building.

title: Why is Trump demolishing the White House’s East Wing? Because he wants to
summary: The 123-year-old East Wing of the White House is now a pile of rubble. After Trump said in July that the historic building would not be touched, it was stealthily bulldozed to make way for a $300m ballroom. According to Trump, there was a teeny little change of plans “after really a tremendous amount of study with some of the best architects in the world” But the bulldozing went ahead without any such thing being submitted to the National Capital Planning Commission, the federal agency that oversees construction and renovations to government building. Trump has said the new 90,000 sq ft ballroom is going to be “paid for 100% by me and some friends of mine” Now the world's CEOs have a wonderful opportunity to prove just how friendly to Trump they are. Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft and Google have already lined up to contribute to the project. Defense contractors including Lockheed Martin and Palantir – who seem to know a thing or two about reducing beloved buildings to rubble.

title: Everybody panic – the workplace has become too ‘feminized’!
summary: The New York Times published a transcript of a recent episode of the conservative columnist Ross Douthat’s podcast Interesting Times. The piece was originally titled: Did Women Ruin the Workplace? The headline was then changed to the more nuanced: Did Liberal Feminism Ruin the workplace? Helen Andrews, a critic of liberal feminism, explained that #MeToo was woke, college campuses are too woke, and “the law is currently lopsided in favor of punishing male vices and allowing feminized vices totally free rein” In response to a question about what constitutes “feminine vices”, Andrews explains that women like “gossiping” and have an “inability to deal with conflict directly” While the Times is busy pondering whether liberal feminism has ruined the workplace, women are being rolled back around the world. The leader of Mexico can’t do her own job without being harassed in public, and the Times wants us to consider whether the workplace has been too feminized.

title: Where is the Gaza ‘peace process’ really going?
summary: The banner read “Peace 2025”, while Palestine’s representatives were barred from the room. Like clockwork, this “peace” has already eroded with Israel violating the ceasefire through continued bombardments. In the first month, Israel has broken its own agreement at least 100 times: at least 200 murdered, the yellow line breached, food and fuel blocked, reconstruction prevented. The genocide never ends; it only modulates between active slaughter and slow strangulation. The fact that Israel's occupation and colonial expansion has continued unpunished by international authorities since 1967 is proof enough that they will never be held to the fire they started. They learned from American history between 30 million and 60 million buffalo roamed North America until the U.S. military deliberately slaughtered them to reduce their population. Not only is there no threat to Palestinian existence, but Hamas hides because there are fewer Palestinians to control than there were Native Americans to control. This is why Israel destroys not just people but the survival of itself: the water treatment plants, the agricultural fields, every university, every hospital.

title: He told the world what was happening in El Fasher. Then they sought him out. How Sudan lost ‘a true hero of the war’
summary: Mohamed Khamis Douda was the official spokesperson for Zamzam, the displacement camp in Sudan’s Darfur region. He had been in regular contact with the Guardian, describing daily survival in a place that for months has seemed doomed to fall to the RSF. In the months leading to El Fasher's fall, he said it felt as if he was being followed by drones. Many nights were spent inside a crude bomb shelter made from a metal container buried in the ground. He balanced his struggle for survival with trying to support those around him. He documented rights abuses while also organising burials for the dead. He believed it was this that attracted the ire of theRSF, when he shared information about Colombian mercenaries fighting on the peripheries of El FASHER. His friends and family have confirmed to the Guardian that DoudA has been killed. The RSF have been expelled. There are 60 martyrs and 100 injured. I went with my friend Ahmed to visit the wounded – there were countless women and children hit by stray bullets.

title: Ministers can raise taxes if they come out fighting. But no one in this cowardly Labour government seems able
summary: In less than a month, the government will unveil a budget that will be huge in scope, and hugely painful. The public is likely to pick up a tab for £20-30bn in tax rises and spending cuts. This government is constitutionally incapable of such a thing, because that would involve picking sides and making enemies. The lack of argument is why all those earnest academics cannot discern an actual Starmerism, why the prime minister’s speeches are such utter blancmange. But it is about to prove highly damaging, perhaps even fatal. A few of us long ago warned that strapping oneself into a budgetary straitjacket was as unnecessary as any stunt by Ed Truss. That vacuum should be filled by the right in both parliament and the press, who will bang on about a lying government (which is fair) and a fiscal crisis. This weekend, they should be filling in Laura Kuenssberg about the expensive and arduous mission to fix a broken country. And preparing taxpayers for exactly how they’ll have to cough up.

title: ‘They told me not to speak out’: the woman who took on China – and won her husband’s freedom
summary: Zeynure and Idris Hasan are Uyghurs, a mostly Muslim ethnic group in China. They fled to Turkey in the 2010s, believing they would be safe in exile. But leaving Turkey proved to be a terrible mistake when Idris was arrested in Morocco. Zeynure says Chinese officials let him board the flight knowing he would be arrested when he arrived in Morocco and told he was going to be deported to China. She says: ‘I had to do something to do my husband – to tell the truth to the world. Everyone knows Uy Ghurs sent to China will die. They pushed me out.’ The second was as a Muslim UyGHur in Xinjiang, cut short by teachings of “communist songs” and being banned from going to the mosque or going to Ramadan. It was too beautiful, like a scene from a story from a beautiful, beautiful novel. The third was as an English teacher in Istanbul, helping to publish news and printed works.

title: Powerful Afghan earthquake leaves at least 20 dead and hundreds injured
summary: Powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn on Monday. At least 20 people dead and more than 640 others injured, 25 critically. US Geological Survey said quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm. In August, an earthquake in eastern Afghanistan killed more than 2,200 people. The impoverished country often faces difficulty in responding to such natural disasters, especially in remote regions. The earthquake was also felt in Mazar-i-Sharif, the capital of the northern Balkh province, where footage on social media showed slight damage to the historic Blue Mosque. In the nearby province of Badakhshan, the quake partly or completely destroyed 800 houses in one village, a police spokesman said.

title: Sudan’s brutal civil war – what has happened in El Fasher?
summary: Rapid Support Forces captured El Fasher from the army after an 18-month siege. The development raises the possibility the country could face partition. The RSF has been accused of killing hundreds of unarmed civilians in ethnically motivated attacks. Yale University’s Humanitarian Research Lab has said the level of violence is comparable to the first 24 hours of the Rwandan genocide. Videos have emerged showing “dozens of unarmed men being shot or lying dead, surrounded by RSF fighters”, according to the UN. The US, UN and others have also determined that the RSf has committed genocide and mass rape against ethnic Masalit and non-Arab communities in Darfur. In April, the RSF killed as many as 2,000 people when it seized the Zamzam camp for displaced people.

title: Kathryn Bell obituary
summary: Kathryn Bell was a founder member of several organisations promoting creativity and human rights. In 1976, Kathryn and her partner, Elsa Wallace Beckett, a wheelchair-user, set up Gemma, a support and social network in London for lesbians with disabilities. In 1999, in the face of mainstream publishers’ seeming indifference to LGBTQ+ writing, she was instrumental in setting up and administering an authors’ collective, which became Paradise Press. Kathryn was a fine writer of short stories and poetry. Examples of her work appear in anthologies, but she was more concerned with promoting Elsa’s work and also encouraging and nurturing others with feedback and advice. Kathryn continued to run GAW and Gemma until forced by ill-health to hand over the work. She is survived by two cousins, William and Anne. Elsa died in 2019.

title: Wednesday briefing: Making sense of the Maccabi Tel Aviv saga, where law and disorder fumbled with fandom
summary: Maccabi Tel Aviv say they will decline any allocation even if ban is reversed. Club says 'hate-filled falsehoods' have created a 'toxic atmosphere' Government's efforts to make their attendance possible are now academic. But it also heads off a potential nightmare scenario for those in the UK who have decried the ban: Maccabi fans being allowed to attend, and serious disorder breaking out as a result. We try to unpick a tortuous political saga where fandom and antisemitism once again became a political football. Here are the five big stories you need to know today: Ukraine, Boris Johnson, Covid inquiry, Nazir Afzal, Living Wage and Coal use in the world. Back to Mail Online home.Back to the page you came from. Back To the pageyou came from: Covid-19, MailOnline home, Mail Online news, Daily Mail home, Sportsmail home, Newsquiz, iReport, and more.

title: My dad cursed our family and left us. But after his death, he followed me everywhere
summary: My father died nine months ago and last night he drove me home in a taxi. We knew something was wrong when my father stopped taking his insulin and started leaving his flat at night without his shoes because there were ‘people in the plants’ After several tests, he was diagnosed with Lewy body dementia, which causes hallucinations and a rapid decline in cognition. He moved to a nursing home in central Stockholm, and I told myself everything would end well. Dad would finally get proper medication, physical therapy, new teeth, foot care and eye treatment for his declining vision. I imagined coming by with my sons, and we would finally be able to talk about everything: why he disappeared, what we might have done differently and why I still held on to the naive hope that he would apologise. After their first kiss, Dad asked Mom what her family name, Bergman, meant in Swedish. “Mountain man,” she said. He couldn’t believe it. He was a 21-year-old Tunisian store detective, using his impeccable eyesight to catch shoplifters in a mall in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Wednesday briefing: The new, devastating flood risk facing nearly all of Britain
summary: Millions more homes across England, Scotland and Wales are at risk of devastating floods. In England alone, the number of properties exposed to flooding is expected to rise by more than a quarter, from 6.3m to 8m. The story gets worse for those in high-risk areas for flash flooding, where the frequency could surge by up to 66% by 2050. The picture is so bleak that, startlingly, some towns may one day have to be abandoned altogether. This time, however, the warnings are not coming from environmental campaigners but from leaders in the insurance industry. They warn that large swathes of housing and commercial property in densely populated areas are among the most vulnerable to devastating flooding. In Bermondsey and Old Southwark in London, and Boston and Skegness in Lincolnshire, about 90% of homes could be at risk from river and coastal flooding by 2050 – that is the highest proportions anywhere in the country. The global economy has shown “unexpected resilience” to Donald Trump’s tariffs, but the full impact is yet to be felt, the IMF has warned.

title: Trump and his media buddies are taking the muddling of reality to a whole new level
summary: Trump appeared on CBS News’s 60 Minutes on Sunday night for his first sit-down with the show in five years. He commented on how much better the network has become after its owner, Paramount, was taken over by his billionaire allies, the father-and-son duo Larry and David Ellison. If you watched the interview on TV, you might have missed that particular bit because (weird!) it didn’t get aired. Trump-friendly editing of an interview conducted by a network now owned by the president's allies, with a head of news that he thinks is “great”, is part of a broader trend of US media outlets lying down and rolling over for Trump. Take Elon Musk, who helped propel Trump to his second term. First Musk bought Twitter – a very convenient way of controlling online discourse – and now he has launched his own AI-powered version of Wikipedia called Grokipedia.

title: President JD Vance or Marco Rubio? We’re seeing the first signs of the battle over Trump’s succession
summary: JD Vance and Marco Rubio, vice-president and secretary of state respectively, are the two names Trump picked out as his most likely successors. Trump predicted a two-horse race for the 2028 Republican nomination. Vance and Rubio have already shown themselves to be unsuited to high office. It’s a choice between a pit bull and a poodle. If Vance does run, he will have to spell out what he believes. The problem is, he doesn’t know. He once dismissed Trump as an ‘idiot’ he would “never” support. Now he himself does exactly that, all the time. Rubio is an altogether quieter, strangely passive figure and possibly the most ineffectual secretary ofState of recent times. While Trump hogs the spotlight on Israel and China, Rubio acts as prop cheerman to make sense of his ill-considered, hyped-up deals – an impossible task at which he fails daily.

title: ‘This was a slaughter, not an operation’: the favela reeling from Rio’s deadliest police raid
summary: Dozens of corpses were splayed out along the favela’s main drag after more than 130 people were killed during the deadliest police operation in Rio's history. “I’ve brought 53 down myself … there must be another 12 or 15 up there in the bush,” said Erivelton Vidal Correia, the head of the local residents’ association. Rio officials said on Tuesday that at least 64 people, including four police officers, had been killed after a force of 2,500 launched a pre-dawn assault on Alemão and Penha, the vast patchwork of favelas of which Vila Cruzeiro is part. Most of the corpses were unclothed but a few wore ghillie suits, camouflage clothing used by snipers, hunters and nature photographers to conceal themselves in foliage. But there was fury among the scores of people who had flocked to the plaza and who claimed police had summarily executed the young men instead of detaining them.

title: ‘History is repeating itself’: fight against far-right in London’s East End goes on
summary: It was 89 years ago this month that local people drove out Oswald Mosley’s Blackshirt militia from Whitechapel in the East End . In the decades since, the National Front, the BNP and the English Defence League have all tried to carve out a foothold in the area . This week, London’s police stopped the hard right UK Independence Party (Ukip) from staging a ‘crusade on Whitechapel’ in the borough of Tower Hamlets . While this weekend’s Ukip march has been stopped, counter-protesters still plan to gather in Whitechapel on Saturday . For Rosenberg, the repeated battle against the far right reflects two different visions of working-class life – one diverse, the other homogenous . But for months, tensions have been simmering in Tower Hamlets, as rightwingers have made its diversity the centre of a culture war . Last week, Safia Jama, the 47-year-old CEO of the charity Women’s Inclusive Team, was chairing a Stand Up to Racism meeting when it was disrupted by rightwing protesters .

title: Support for Reform UK increasing among British Indians, poll shows
summary: Support for Reform UK among British Indians has tripled since the election . Support for Nigel Farage's party has jumped from 4% to 13% in a year . British Indians are becoming increasingly important swing voters . For decades they were closely allied with the Labour party . Social conservatism among Indian voters and growing nationalism among Hindus in particular have helped drive them further right on the political spectrum . Research shows the shift is being driven in part by changing policy priorities . While Indian voters always put education at the top of their concerns, their second priority has changed from health five years ago to the economy now .  Equalities and human rights has dropped from fifth on the list of priorities to seventh . As economic and social frustrations deepen, both major parties may face growing pressure to engage more directly with the community .

title: We are heartbroken after synagogue attack, says senior UK Jewish politician
summary: Richard Hermer said tackling a rising tide of antisemitism would require police protection and political leaders calling it out wherever it was found . The country’s most senior lawyer made the intervention in Jewish News . He said more must be done to tackle antisemitism and to bring communities together . Starmer issued a message to Jewish people on Thursday night pledging to 'wrap arms' around the community in the wake of the attack . In a recorded message, Starmer said: 'I know how much fear you will be holding inside of you. I really do ... Nobody should have to do that'

title: Drag acts, detractors and true-blue diehards: my weird weekend at a Margaret Thatcher festival
summary: Matt Tedford plays the former prime minister in a riotous drag show called Margaret Thatcher: Queen of Soho . The show played at the Guildhall on Monday night . Grantham has never had as much publicity as it has this week . On a wider level, the anniversary has been marked with the usual spume of reassessment . Not everything has been a riotous success: one of the walking tours at the weekend attracted just five people . There has been a new book alleging that she had two extramarital affairs . Unherd article on Thatcher’s 'erotic power' describes her as 'a nursery dominatrix' There are talks and walks, Thatcher-themed music nights and exhibitions of memorabilia . Gyles Brandreth giving a lecture on Thatcher's unlikely connection to Winnie-the-Pooh . Exhibitions of her exercise books at the local school . A photo mosaic of an AI Thatcher, her outfits displayed in a glass case .

title: For some minority Britons the ‘unite the kingdom’ rally shows far-right politics is becoming legitimised
summary: Tommy Robinson's 13 September far-right 'unite the kingdom' rally drew 110,000 people to London . But for some ethnic minority Britons, Saturday's scenes were reminiscent of far-right marches 50 years ago . For ex-servicewoman Hetticia McIntosh, the times evoke memories of her east London, Windrush generation youth . The Home Office inexplicably refused to renew her and her husband’s British passports in the 1970s and 1980s, forcing them to leave the country for St Lucia for decades . She now fears, amid talk of 'remigration' from the far right, hardening attitudes to legal migration in Westminster and a government struggling to convey a positive message of unity . Last week, police in Oldbury, West Midlands received a report that a Sikh woman had been violently sexually assaulted and told: 'You don't belong here, get out' The prospect of a far-right, Elon Musk-backed government no longer seems unthinkable, a representative of the UK Indian Muslim Council said .

title: Reform UK council removes St George and union flags over safety fears
summary: Durham county council has removed flags and bunting displaying the St George’s cross and the union flag . A risk assessment found that arope involved was so strong that, had a high-sided vehicle driven into it, the poles it was attached to could have been pulled down . In the past few weeks there has been increasing controversy over the number of flags being flown in towns across England . Some say it is a show of national pride and patriotism, while others argue the swell of interest in flying flags is linked to the far right and anti-migrant sentiment .  instances of vandalism have been recorded, including red lines being spray-painted on to white roundabouts to replicate the St George's cross . Reform MP Lee Anderson has also posted frequently about his desire for more flags to be flown around the country .

title: UK charities say toxic immigration rhetoric leading to threats against staff
summary: Charities have warned of growing racial abuse, intimidation and threats of violence towards staff and beneficiaries .  Voluntary organisations say they are being forced to introduce extensive security measures to protect staff and property . Refugee and asylum seeker charities, Muslim, Jewish and ethnic minority organisations, women’s groups, youth bodies, homelessness charities and even charity shops have reported being subject to violence, threats and abuse . Incidents include threats to rape and kill staff, verbal and physical abuse of beneficiaries on the street, attempted break-ins to charity-owned accommodation, and vandalism, including anti-migrant and racist graffiti . A coalition of more than 150 charities including Age UK, Citizens Advice and the Muslim Council of Britain has written to the prime minister, Keir Starmer, urging him to challenge the 'cynical' targeting .

title: Starmer will hand Britain over to Farage, says Green party leader Zack Polanski
summary: Polanski condemned what he called Labour's 'managed decline' Condemned the aping of Reform policies in areas such as migration . Polanski, who is Jewish and grew up in Manchester, expressed his horror at the attack on a synagogue in the city on Thursday . His ancestors, who moved to England from Latvia via Ukraine and Poland, still faced antisemitism in the UK . The arrival of the media-savvy Polanski, who won an overwhelming 85% of the membership vote against a joint bid by two of the party’s MPs, has brought the Greens new members and extra attention . Green membership has risen rapidly since Polanski’s victory and climbing to more than 80,000 for the first time, he told the event that it was time for the party to be ambitious .

title: ‘I refuse to be defined by fascism’: daughter of murder victim speaks after death of neo-Nazi killer in prison
summary: Pavlo Lapshyn was found dead in his cell at Wakefield prison on Tuesday . The circumstances of his death have not yet been publicly confirmed . He was convicted at the Old Bailey in October 2013 of murdering Mohammed Saleem . Saleem was a pillar of the local community who was on his way home from evening prayers at the mosque when Lapshyn stabbed him three times in the back and stamped on his head . His daughter Maz Saleem has said she forgives Lapshyn for taking her father’s life in such a brutal and horrific way . She has spent years campaigning against racism and Islamophobia and does not want the murder of her father to continue the cycle of hatred between people from different backgrounds . Maz emphasises that forgiving Lapshyn does not mean she condones what he did . But she believes holding on to hatred serves no one .

title: Jeremy Corbyn to appear in north London panto
summary: Former Labour leader will appear in theatre production of Wicked Witches . He will play the Wizard of Oz-lington and make an onscreen cameo in the show . Corbyn said: 'The Pleasance [theatre] has been at the heart of our community for 30 years and local theatre like this deserves our support' The theatre said: 'Expect soaring vocals, sparkly spells, and more sass than you can shake a wand at' Wicked Witches – A Popular Panto! is at Pleasance London until December 25 . It is Pleasance's first in over 20 years and raises the curtain on its 30th anniversary .

title: Keir Starmer calls student protests on 7 October anniversary ‘un-British’
summary: Starmer said protests showed a lack of respect for others . Added that pro-Palestine protests had been used as excuse to attack Jews . On 7 October 2023 Hamas-led militants killed about 1,200 people . They took 251 hostages during an assault on southern Israel . Israel’s subsequent offensive has so far killed more than 67,000 Palestinians . At least 460 people have died from starvation under Israel’s aid restrictions . The home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, has said repeated large-scale demonstrations have caused 'considerable fear' among the Jewish community . She has pledged to give police greater powers to restrict protests . Tory MP Robert Jenrick called plans for protests in cities including London, Manchester, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Bristol on the anniversary of the attacks 'a fucking disgrace'

title: Sidekick Starmer can’t get a word in as The Donald dominates world’s most one-sided double act
summary: On Saturday Donald Trump had broken the record with a round of just 18. A hole in one at every hole . On the Sunday he had gone one better. So The Donald was in an expansive mood . He waited for Keir Starmer and his wife, Victoria, to pay him a visit .  Clearly, the special relationship still has a way to go . The US president is like a radio presenter on the night-time slot . Uncomfortable with silence. Filling the dead air with a long rambling stream of unconsciousness . No longer just the most important person in his own life but the mostimportant person on the planet . Life doesn’t get any better than this for the supreme narcissist . It was billed as a double act but everyone knew it wasn’t going to be that way . Trump hardly drew breath. A series of rambling, self-congratulatory monologues in which we actually learned very little .

title: Reform wheels out Danny Kruger, the ‘brains’ of Nigel Farage’s operation
summary: Danny Kruger is the latest Reform recruit, having jumped ship from the Tories . He has been entrusted with getting Reform policy ready for the next election . Nige has had years and years of running political parties, and they have never evolved much beyond a one-man band . But this time would be different. Reform promised to be the grownups . Danny would set up a secret phone line to which people could ring in with stories of government waste . It is now the official Reform. Parliament would be sovereign. Apart from the bits that wouldn't be sovereign . At least half of ministers would be Nige's personal appointments. That would probably be the same five departments Labour had already promised to discontinue . The idiocy levels were rising still higher. Sometimes you have to wonder whether he thinks before he speaks . Not that he was in the mood to apologise. Danny is very much old school. Everything is always someone else’s fault. Reform would discontinue the leases of five Whitehall departments.

title: Families of David Amess and Jo Cox voice concern at rise in violent political rhetoric
summary: The families of murdered MPs David Amess and Jo Cox have voiced concern about a recent surge in violent political rhetoric in Britain . There are also concerns over an increasing normalisation of language calling for political figures to be killed . Examples include the suspension of a Reform UK councillor linked to a social media account calling for Keir Starmer to be shot . Elon Musk made comments that drew condemnation from Downing Street when he told the crowd that “violence is coming”. Brendan Cox, who was married to Jo Cox when she was shot and stabbed by a far-right extremist during the EU referendum campaign in 2016, warned high levels of polarisation and division in Britain were making violence more likely . Nigel Farage accused Starmer of inciting violence against Reform UK members by levelling accusations of racism at the party .

title: Kemi Badenoch says she is ‘doing politics differently’ – you can’t argue with that
summary: Kemi Badenoch is this year's leader of the Tory party . The 2024 general election a high point in her party's fortunes . Her personal ratings in freefall. A curiosity . After devoting the first 40 minutes of her Sunday TV show to an interview with Shabana Mahmood, Kuenssberg reluctantly turned her attention to Badenoch . You could tell her heart wasn’t really in it, but she was nothing if not professional . Did Kemi really want to join Russia and Belarus as the only countries not to be signed up? The US and Canada could have been European if they had wanted to be . Only the Tories had the credibility and competence, she said . There was no coherence to anything . All her party had managed to do in the past year or so was to play catch-up . If an apology was off the cards, then so much the better .

title: Nadine Dorries is back – with her incisive thinking and deranged conspiracy theories
summary: Danny Kruger was already looking very queasy when he sat at the back for the Reform press conference in which Nigel Farage revealed his plans for mass deportations of legal migrants . It’s one thing to defect from the Tories. It’s another to be made to look a quarter-wit in the process. Nadine Dorries, though, is another matter . The past isn’t just another country, it’s a parallel universe . She is the unthinking woman’s unthinking woman. A danger to herself but a source of amusement to the rest of us . We last saw Nad on the day of her defection at the Reform party conference in early September. There she had been brought on stage to introduce herself. So much so that Nige had to make an unscheduled appearance on stage to interrupt her and drag her away . But Dorries is now back, giving an interview to Cathy Newman on Channel 4’s Fourcast podcast .

title: ‘Such a vibrant feeling’: Reform UK devotees gather at party conference
summary: Party conference season has kicked off at a time when Nigel Farage’s organisation is enjoying as much as a 15-point lead over Labour . Fervour of the Reform faithful was often as unfiltered as ever . Kieran Mishchuk, an 18-year-old who won Reform's first seat on Swale borough council, had got out of bed before 7am to travel to the conference . Terry Washington, 47, from London was at pains to insist he was 'not tribal' but spoke in evangelical tones about his conversion to Reform . William Payne rattled off what he described as the 'burning priorities' to save Britain, ranging from rolling back attacks on freedom of speech to ensuring that the borders were firmly and securely shut . Kim Anderson, a retired former ambulance worker and one-time Labour voter, had enthusiastically now thrown her lot in with Reform .

title: ‘A class act’: Tim Allan, the former Blair ‘smoother’ recalled to Downing Street
summary: Tim Allan once acknowledged that under Tony Blair’s No 10 press operation it was a mistake that ‘spin doctors became the story’ Now he is returning to Downing Street more than 25 years later at the request of Keir Starmer . A former deputy press secretary under Blair, Allan is a smooth and impeccably well-connected PR man, according to those who have worked with him . But he has a job on his hands to turn around Downing Street’s faltering communications efforts, which are struggling to cut through against Nigel Farage’s noisy populism . There is further potential for controversy over his role as a trustee for the gender critical Sex Matters charity, which he resigned to take on the No 10 job . Stonewall, the LGBTQ+ charity, wrote to Starmer this week objecting to Allan’s role and questioning whether Sex Matters would get undue influence in government .

title: Lammy refers himself to watchdog after fishing illegally with JD Vance
summary: David Lammy referred himself to the Environment Agency after fishing with JD Vance without required licence . Anglers aged 13 and over must hold a rod licence to fish for freshwater species such as carp in England and Wales . Foreign Office said an 'administrative oversight' meant licences had not been obtained in advance . Vance described the foreign secretary as a good friend and 'very, very gracious host' despite his failure to catch a fish . He was greeted by dozens of pro-Palestine protesters bashing pots and pans as he arrived at the luxury Carnell Estate near Kilmarnock in East Ayrshire . Protesters from the Stop Trump Coalition held a 'Vance not welcome' party in nearby Charlbury, attended by about 100 people carrying placards and cakes mocking the Republican politician .

title: Rachel Reeves is the only one grinning wildly at Keir and Kemi’s dreary display
summary: After last week’s mini-meltdown during prime minister’s questions, the chancellor is now condemned to spend the next year grinning manically every time she’s out and about . Sometimes, it’s no fun being a politician. So Rachel Reeves entered the Commons alongside Keir Starmer for this week’s PMQs grinning wildly . It must have taken all Kemi Badenoch’s self-control not to have made fun of the chancellor . Kemi is hardwired to kick an opponent when she’s down. But well done Kemi for doing the right thing. Unfortunately for her that was about the only thing she did get right . Not that Starmer himself was on sparkling form. The chaos of the welfare bill has clearly ground him down . This PMQs was just another chore to be ticked off the list . Perhaps Kemi knows something the rest of us don’t. Maybe Saffron Walden is wall-to-wall multimillionaires.

title: Keir Starmer in diplomatic push to head off Middle East crisis before G7 summit in Canada
summary: Keir Starmer is beginning an urgent diplomatic push to head off the crisis in the Middle East . Earlier on Sunday, the Foreign Office warned Britons not to travel to Israel . It marks the biggest escalation of UK travel advice since October 2023 . Downing Street did not rule out the possibility of having to evacuate UK nationals from Israel if matters deteriorated . Starmer discussed the continuing clashes between Israel and Iran with the Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, in Ottawa . He is now heading to the G7 summit in Kananaskis, in the western province of Alberta . While Starmer’s programme for meetings at the summit has yet to be set out, it is likely he will hold bilateral talks with leaders such as President Donald Trump .

title: Three neo-Nazis jailed for plotting terror attacks on UK mosques and synagogues
summary: Christopher Ringrose, 35, Marco Pitzettu, 26, and Brogan Stewart, 25, were jailed for between eight and 11 years . They were planning terrorist attacks on mosques and synagogues in England . The trio idolised Hitler and the Nazis, used racist slurs, glorified mass murderers and encouraged violence against anyone deemed an enemy . Stewart styled himself as the 'Fhrer' and laid down uniform rules for members to be dressed in Nazi-style clothing . An undercover officer called Blackheart was appointed as the 'Obergruppenfhrer' in the group, jurors heard . Ringrose had also 3D-printed most of the components of a semi-automatic firearm at the time of his arrest and was trying to obtain the remaining parts .

title: Badenoch urged to ‘come clean’ after doubt cast on Stanford University claim
summary: Labour and the Lib Dems have called for Kemi Badenoch to come clean about her claims of an offer from Stanford University at the age of 16 . Former admissions staff said she had described an impossible scenario . Labour MP Peter Prinsley has written to Badenoch saying she should lay out the specifics of how the alleged offer came about . The Lib Dem education spokesperson, Munira Wilson, said Badenoch risked undermining trust . Badenoch has defended her claim to have received an offer as a teenager in Nigeria from the elite university to study medicine . She said she was offered a place on exam results alone, and was offered a partial scholarship . But former admissions staff and US academics have told the Guardian that Stanford has never made offers based only on SATs .

title: Doubts cast on Kemi Badenoch’s claim of US medical school offer
summary: Doubts have surfaced over Kemi Badenoch's claim to have been offered a place at a prestigious US medical school at 16 . Conservative leader has said she was offered a place and a partial scholarship to study medicine at Stanford University in California . But medicine is only offered to graduates at Stanford and there is no pre-med degree . Academic and admissions experts have cast doubt on this, saying it was an impossible scenario . One senior US academic said he had never heard of any exemptions – not even for internationally renowned child prodigies or royalty . A spokesperson for Badenoch said: 'Nearly 30 years ago, and aged 16, Kemi was offered a part-scholarship at Stanford that her parents couldn’t afford to take up. But, given her subsequent degrees in both engineering and law are a matter of public record, she questions the hysterical efforts to disprove this, from people who showed little interest in probing Rachel Reeves' hole-filled CV that has contributed to the economic crisis engulfing our country'

title: Journey times up, deaths down: Welsh 20mph speed limit still divisive two years on
summary: Collisions along roads that have changed from 30mph to 20mph decreased by 19% in 2024 compared with 2023 . 100 fewer people a year have been killed or badly hurt in road traffic accidents, according to Welsh government figures . More than 130,000 drivers – or 34% of people with licences in Wales – have been caught breaking the lower limit since it was introduced . The most recent YouGov polling, from a year ago, found seven in 10 people opposed the 20mph default . Newport council has named 14 roads where the speed limit will go up again, while in Blaneau Gwent one road has changed back, and in Ceredigion no changes are planned . Ken Skates, who took over as transport cabinet secretary in March 2024, was forced into a partial climbdown, giving councils £5m to reassess local speed limits .

title: ‘A palette unlike anything in the west’: Ben Okri, Yinka Shonibare and more on how Nigerian art revived Britain’s cultural landscape
summary: Some primal energy was unleashed among Nigerian artists in the years leading up to independence . Artists across the country, in constant dialogue with one another, created works that evoked their traditions but in a contemporary context . Their work helped the nation to reconnect with its ancient ways, but adapted to modern times . Nigerian modernism is, in many ways, about identity – about how to live with the legacy of colonialism and create something that feels both contemporary and connected to the past . Being British-Nigerian means you are constantly navigating both worlds, which is ripe for creative opportunity . For too long, African art has been viewed through the lens of European artists who were influenced by it, such as Picasso . This exhibition centres Nigerian artists on their own terms . The tradition continues with artists such as El Anatsui, who has expanded the possibilities of global sculpture with his monumental works, and ceramicist Ladi Kwali, who alchemised Nigerian craft and modern design .

title: Louis CK defends decision to perform at Riyadh comedy festival as ‘a good opportunity’
summary: Louis CK has defended his decision to perform at the Riyadh comedy festival in Saudi Arabia . Other comedians have criticised the big names taking part as whitewashing a regime guilty of human rights abuses . Dave Chappelle, Bill Burr, Kevin Hart, Pete Davidson, Whitney Cummings, Aziz Ansari, Hannibal Burress, Jim Jefferies, Jo Koy, Tom Segura and Jeff Ross are among the lineup at Riyadh comedy festival . Several comedians have questioned the ethics of performing comedy at a festival directly paid for by the Saudi Arabian government . Human Rights Watch argued the festival was an effort by the Saudi government to whitewash its actions including a crackdown on free speech . Kirson, who performed at the Riyadh festival on 29 September, said she had asked for a guarantee that she could talk about being a lesbian on stage . But she added: “At the same time, I deeply regret participating under the auspices of the Saudi government”.

title: A drag queen stands at a site of violence: Lee-Ann Olwage’s best photograph
summary: Lee-Ann Olwage is a photographer based in Cape Town, South Africa . Her work explores gender and identity in the country . She worked with drag queens to photograph them in places where violence had happened . The series is part of the World Press Photo print sale, 17-26 November, in celebration of the event's 70th anniversary . Lee-Ann's work is available to buy at the print sale and her CV is available to view at World Press Photo’s website. To order your print, visit: http://www.worldpressphoto.com/shop/ Lee-Ann-Olwage’s images will be available to buy from 17-26 November. For more information, see www.lee-Ann-olwage.com .

title: Get ready to rumble: how wrestling broke out of the ring and on to the stage
summary: The Wrestling, as it was then called, won the Edinburgh comedy award . Clash of the Comics is about to take over the Hammersmith Apollo . For the first time it will stand outside a wider comedy festival . The lineup includes pro wrestlers Simon Miller, Cara Noir and La Cyclonica . It's one of the few performance art forms where the reaction of the crowd informs what will happen . There is an element of danger, as shows teeter between planned and improvised . Heather Bandenberg stumbled upon wrestling by accident, quickly falling for the space it allowed her to take up . Wrestling has never been a great place to be a woman . You’re training to be a gymnast and you’re doing elements of stunt . One of the early moves a wrestler learns is how to “bump”, the classic move where they throw themselves on to the floor in order to imitate the impact of being thrown by someone else .

title: From One Battle After Another to the Turner prize: your complete entertainment guide to the week ahead
summary: Cinema One Battle After Another Out is a loose adaptation of Thomas Pynchon’s Vineland starring Leonardo DiCaprio . The Strangers: Chapter 2 Out is the fourth film in the Strangers home-invasion horror franchise, which claims to be based on a true story . Head for Bradford, this year’s UK city of culture, to find out as the shortlisted artists strut their stuff. The Magnetic Fields’ sixth album 69 Love Songs has rightly taken up classic status. Packed full of pin-sharp vignettes couched in country, synthpop, folk and jazz, it will be played in full across two nights, in three cities. The BBC National Orchestra of Wales marks the 50th anniversary of the death of Shostakovich with a performance of his most massive symphony, No 7 in C, the Leningrad . Rachel Aroesti Bacchae National Theatre: Olivier Whitworth, London, 1 October to 8 March This artist of memory made prints that are almost as lush as his paintings. Hodgkin’s works on paper get a lavish showing here, in an exhibition that is also a chance to ponder his legacy.

title: Bill Burr calls critics of Riyadh comedy festival ‘sanctimonious’ and ‘phoney’
summary: Bill Burr has defended his appearance at the Riyadh comedy festival . He called his critics 'sanctimonious cunts' and said he had a 'good time' Burr appeared alongside Kevin Hart, Louis CK, Aziz Ansari and Dave Chappelle . Human Rights Watch called event a distraction from the 'soaring number of executions' in Saudi Arabia . David Cross wrote that he was 'disgusted' in a statement . Burr said he felt 'wonderful' about his appearance and doesn't 'give a fuck what all these phoney fucking people are saying' He also said the US was 'moving towards' Saudi Arabia with Ice 'fucking grabbing moms and dads and sticking them in a van for making illegally made fucking tacos'

title: ‘Dictator-for-life vibes’: our architecture critic on Trump’s bulletproof ballroom bling
summary: Donald Trump has decreed the East Wing not fit for purpose . He plans to replace it with a faux classical bulletproof ballroom . It is one of the most grandiose White House projects in a century . On re-assuming the presidency, one of his first executive orders – under the title Making Federal Architecture Beautiful Again – mandated that ‘traditional and classical architecture’ should be the preferred style for all federal public buildings . AIA is extremely concerned about any revisions that remove control from local communities, mandate official federal design preferences, or otherwise hinder design freedom, and add bureaucratic hurdles for federal buildings. Trump’s record as a ‘patron’ of architecture has been shaped by his career as a property developer . His fetishisation of classicism, a historically recurring comfort blanket for despots of all stripes, is bleakly predictable .

title: Stephen Colbert on Trump’s White House East Wing demolition: ‘So deeply unsettling’
summary: On Monday, as part of his White House renovation project to construct a gilded ballroom, Trump sent out a backhoe to rip off a part of the East Wing . Stephen Colbert: 'It's like being a kid and seeing your teacher at the grocery store ... for sale ... in the meat department' Seth Meyers: 'If I had three years left on a lease, I wouldn’t even put up a shelf' Michael Kosta: 'The government shutdown is now in its third week, and there’s no end in sight. But not to worry – President Trump is working day and night ... to build a ballroom!' More than a dozen airports across the country have refused to play a partisan video of the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, at TSA checkpoints .

title: Seth Meyers on Trump’s White House ballroom: ‘This couldn’t be any more of a bait and switch’
summary: Late-night hosts mocked Donald Trump's demolition of the East Wing of the White House . Stephen Colbert said it was 'a lot of history being smashed to rubble' Seth Meyers said it was like a sequel to Fixer Upper called Fucked Upper . The Daily Show's Michael Kosta tracked the swift evolution of the project . Amazon, Apple, Comcast, Google, Microsoft, T-Mobile, Meta Platforms and Hard Rock International have funded it . Estimated cost has risen from an initial $250m to over $300m, for a 90,000 sq-ft (8,400 sq-meter) construction, larger than the existing White House itself . East Wing was built in 1902 and had been the headquarters for presidential spouses since the Carter administration . First lady Melania was in the East Wing, and Colbert hopes they got her out of there .

title: Bob Vylan ‘not regretful’ about IDF chant at Glastonbury: ‘I’d do it again tomorrow’
summary: Punk duo sparked controversy when they led chants of 'death to the IDF' at Glastonbury . US state department revoked member's visas, forcing them to cancel North American tour . Bob Vylan was dropped by its agency UTA, and the US state department revoked the member’s visas . Speaking on The Louis Theroux Podcast in his first interview since Glastonbury, Vylan was asked if he would do it all again . He replied: 'Oh yeah. Like what if I was to go on Glastonbury again tomorrow, yes I would do it again. I’m not regretful of it. I’d do it again tomorrow, twice on Sundays' Vylan also hit back at Damon Albarn from Blur, who called the chant 'spectacular misfire' and described him as 'goose-stepping in tennis gear'

title: Basslines over goalposts, cricket club bhangra nights: the gatherings where British diaspora music really grows
summary: I don't learn about music from record shops or curated playlists . The sounds that have shaped me as a Black British person aren't designed by algorithms or commissioned by labels . They come from speakers balanced on trestle tables, bhangra basslines and WhatsApp threads buzzing long after everyone has gone home . I remember the first time a track reached me through a WhatsApp group that no algorithm would ever find . These diasporic exchanges and cultural networks are pushed to the margins of Britain’s mainstream music narrative . Despite their energy and influence, they rarely receive the same visibility or institutional support as other scenes . That matters, because it speaks to whose voices are amplified as part of the national story, and whose contributions are left unheard . For me, these networks are the reason I fell in love with music in the first place .

title: Chappell Roan review – pop’s patient princess triumphantly takes the throne in New York
summary: Missouri-born pop artist languished in up-and-coming mode for years . Just 18 months ago, she was playing 2,000-cap amphitheaters in mid-sized cities . By summer’s end, she drew the largest crowd that Chicago’s Lollapalooza festival has ever seen . Her return to New York at Forest Hills stadium this weekend was her first live shows in the US in a year . A 93-minute set containing almost every song she’s recorded had the feeling of a greatest hits show . Ran is easily one of the strongest vocalists of her pop generation . But for all the pop bombast, she often let the audience take over . She played every other royal role in a loosely fairytale-themed show .

title: From Bugonia to All’s Fair: your complete entertainment guide to the week ahead
summary: Yorgos Lanthimos returns with a black comedy starring Emma Stone and Jesse Plemons . Riz Ahmed plays a dodgy corporation and an individual with the potential to expose their corrupt practices need to talk . Palestine 36 is the Palestinian entry for the best international film at the Oscars . Jack and George Barnett take their fifth album, Crooked Wing, on tour . Makropulos Case has taken 99 years for one of the 20th century’s greatest operas to reach Covent Garden . The Shelter of Stories takes us on adventures and journeys but always begin and end at home, as sure as Bilbo Baggins returned to the Shire . Jane Bown’s craggy image of Samuel Beckett is one of her most memorable. She also took black-and-white pictures of a young David Hockney, a laughing Mick Jagger and many more . Andrew Jurd introduces her powerful new folk-influenced record Rites & Revelations on this tour .

title: ‘She’s leaning into the idea that her image is a gilded fantasy’: how Taylor Swift embraced the showgirl
summary: Taylor Swift returns with her 12th album in yet another guise: a showgirl . She made The Life of a Showgirl with Swedish super-producers Max Martin and Shellback while touring Europe last year . Album imagery by fashion photographers Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott shows Swift bejewelled with diamantes, fishnet tights, fur and feathered headdresses . Swift isn’t the first pop star to draw from the 19th-century showgirl tradition .  Shania Twain donned a top hat and tuxedo jacket to transform the original’s sleaze into sex appeal and female empowerment . Lady Marmalade, from the Moulin Rouge! soundtrack, emphasised showgirls’ solidarity. Kylie Minogue chose to celebrate her ‘long-term relationship’ with fans with her art deco-inspired Showgirl tour of 2005; Lady Gaga acknowledged her debt to cabaret at last year’s Paris Olympics . Among pop’s new generation, the showgirl offers both stage-ready looks and historical context – but she has never been mere spectacle, argues Alison J Carr .

title: ‘The label made 500 copies – we sold it in corner shops’: the story behind lost dance music classic Punjabi Disco
summary: Kuljit Bhamra’s nine-track album was recorded in London in 1982 . It combines producer Kuljit’s synthesiser melodies and hammering drum machine rhythms with the Punjabi-language folk singing of his classically trained mother, Mohinder Kaur Bhamra . The record was a futuristic outlier: the south Asian fusion sounds of bhangra were only just beginning . Limited to only 500 copies, Punjabi Disco disappeared from circulation almost as quickly as it was released . In the decades since, rare copies have materialised online for thousands of dollars but it has otherwise vanished into obscurity . Now, Kuljit has agreed to release a reissue on his archival label Naya Beat .  Punjabi Disco, Naya Beat, £24.99. Punjabi Disco is out now on PIAS . kuljitbhamra.com and PIAS.org.uk . Punjabi Disco, NayaBeat.com, £9.99. Punjabi Disco, PIAS, £14.99.

title: Garden Reflexxx: the 10 funniest things we have ever seen (on the internet)
summary: FBi Radio are film-makers-cum-critics and aim to free cinema from privilege . In preparation for our upcoming film festival at the Sydney Opera House, we went Tomb Raider to mine the oceanic crust of our search history . Most of these videos are secretly solo acts: usually Women on the Verge of a Mental Breakthrough using available equipment like an iPhone . Ask two film-makers to write a listicle and you give them a job for life . Here are six of the best films we've seen so far this year . The Movies Movies Movies festival runs from September 26 to October 2 at the Opera House in Sydney . For more information, visit the FBi Radio website or the Movies Movies Movies Facebook page . Follow FBi Radio on Twitter @FbiRadio and on Instagram @FBiRadio . Like us on Facebook . Send them your favourite film clips to mailonline@dailymail.co.uk .

title: Jon Stewart on Trump’s Gatsby party: ‘The theme was apparently gross income inequality’
summary: Late-night hosts reacted to Donald Trump Great Gatsby-themed Halloween party held just hours before millions of Americans lost their food stamp benefits . Jon Stewart mocked House speaker Mike Johnson’s insistence that Trump is ‘desperate for Snap benefits to flow to the American people’ Stephen Colbert noted that Trump’s ‘disapproval rating’ is 63% . Seth Meyers touched on Trump’s redecoration of a White House bathroom to befit his imaginable . Jimmy Kimmel said the party felt like the last big bash before the Epstein files come out and it could take months because it declined to dip into other contingency pots to find the full $8bn required to fund the program . Kimmel: 'He just wants them to lose their health insurance. He wants them to eat, but health insurance? No' Seth Meyers: 'Trump and food is like JFK and sex, or Thomas Jefferson and sex and Lincoln and his hat, which he had sex with'

title: Danny Thompson obituary
summary: Danny Thompson was a founder member of the British folk-rock band Pentangle . He added depth and resonance to recordings by artists as varied as Nick Drake and Kate Bush . Thompson, who has died aged 86, was a musician’s musician . His fluid playing enriched the albums Five Leaves Left (1969) by Drake and Solid Air (1973) by Martyn . After Pentangle split in 1972, Thompson chose not to join another group . However, in the late 70s, Thompson sobered up and the reverence his recordings with Drake and Martyn were now held in demand as a session player . In 1987 Thompson released his debut solo album, Whatever, leading a jazz trio playing the muscular fusion he loved . Last year, he performed at Richard Thompson’s 75th birthday concert at the Royal Albert Hall . For confidential support call the Samaritans in the UK on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here .

title: Jack DeJohnette obituary
summary: Jack DeJohnette was one of the most creative and viscerally thrilling exponents of jazz art . He played genres from R&B to free-jazz in his hometown, Chicago . DeJohnette contributed to Miles Davis’s landmark early-1970s electric bands . His resourceful subtlety in quieter acoustic settings was never blunted . On uptempo swingers, he could sustain a blur of surging patterns . An athletic, muscular drummer who played the kit at arm’s length as if boxing with it, he could maintain thundering funk/rock grooves for long stretches . In his later years he toured and recorded occasionally as a solo pianist . The experience of DeJohnette live onstage was always enthralling, but his charisma was never a distraction from whatever music he was there to bring to life . Died aged 83, he was the only child of Eva (ACM Wood) and Jack De Johnette Sr .

title: Donna Jean Godchaux supplied steel and soul to the Grateful Dead in their prime
summary: Donna Jean Godchaux was not a fan of the Grateful Dead when she arrived in California in 1970 . By the end of the Dead’s set at the Winterland Ballroom, Thatcher – ostensibly retired from music – had announced: 'If I sing again, it will be with this band' Godchaux’s eight-year tenure with the band came to define her . On one notable occasion during the Europe ’72 tour, Godchaux took to the stage having taken 15 hits of LSD . In her account, she spent most of the show lying prone under her husband’s piano, but somehow still made it to the microphone in time to sing . Her timing in joining the Dead was fortuitous: their sound had taken a turn for the rootsy with Vaults Workingman’s Dead and American Beauty . The band’s usual source of traditionally soulful vocals, the blues-influenced keyboard player Ron McKernan, was ailing, stricken by the alcoholism that hastened his death in 1973 .

title: Jon Stewart on Trump’s taunts of an illegal third term: ‘We know he’s thought about it’
summary: Latenight hosts reacted to Donald Trump's taunts about an illegal third presidential term and his demolition of the East Wing of the White House . Jon Stewart: Running as the vice-president to skirt the 22nd amendment isn’t cute. But he’s kinda guy who’s like ‘I respect Americans too much to play games’ Seth Meyers: It’s so weird to make a hat for a thing that can’t happen, without permission, without permission. I wish the master builder would master-build in private like the rest of us do . Jimmy Kimmel: The unrest continues to rage out of control. This terrorists are destroying government – oh wait, that’s the White House. He’s in it for a week and we should’ve made him put down a security deposit!” Kimmel: People in other countries think what Trump tells us about our country. They're worried about us in the same way you worry about a nephew who maybe haven't seen for a few years missing all of his front teeth?

title: Jimmy Kimmel on the Republicans: ‘So much greed and hypocrisy and duplicity’
summary: Latenight hosts spoke about Donald Trump's attempts to transform the White House . Kimmel named a number of tech companies, including Meta and Google, who all 'lined up to eat beef stroganoff and kiss his ass' Kimmel said there is 'so much greed and hypocrisy and duplicity' in the party . Stephen Colbert also spoke about Trump’s 'Cinderella ballroom' and the dinner attended by investors . He called it a 'demented version of Cinderella where the pumpkin is in charge' Colbert joked that if you wanted to reveal horrors from Hitler's past, just show a deep dish pizza . This week has also seen leaked chats including chats depicting Hitler in Chicago . Young Republicans have also been sharing videos depicting Hitler as a baby .

title: Laurence Fox’s libel claim over racism accusations to go to retrial
